summary: A bench of Justice Dipak Misra and Justice Anil Dave has granted leave to a Rajasthan government employee to appeal against an order of the Rajasthan High Court which had dismissed his plea for quashing of a circular issued in 1992. A circular was issued by the then Chief Minister of Rajasthan, Vasundhara Raje, in the month of January, 1993 to all the Chief Ministers of the State of Rajasthan:- “If a stagnated employee is to be given a promotion, his pay would be fixed directly in the second or third selection grade as the case may be with reference to pay being drawn immediately before grant of the second or third selection grade. or third selection grade straightway in terms of this order, his pay would be fixed directly in the second or third selection grade as the case may be with reference to pay being drawn immediately before grant of the second or third selection grade.” The aforesaid circular was issued to avoid stagnation in certain categories of service with the objective that a stagnated employee should get the next pay-scale available for the promotional post without availing the promotion because of lack of vacancies after completion of 9, 18 and 27 years of service. Ltd against the order of the Division Bench of High Court quashing the First Information Report (FIFR) of the appellant in the case of Gold Quest International Pte. The Supreme Court of India has been asked to decide whether it is permissible for the High Court to quash criminal proceedings or the first information report or complaint filed by the wife under Sections 498-A and 406 IPC when the offences are non-compoundable. summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person who dies in an accident due to rash and negligent driving by the driver of a truck bearing a truck registration No.HR-56-6047 between Ram Nagar and Dhandhera should be entitled to compensation. The compensation awarded by the Uttarakhand Road Accidents Tribunal in the case of Bindar Singh and Ors on 25 March, 2014 has been set aside by the High Court on the ground that the Tribunal did not follow the principle laid down in Santosh Devi v National Insurance Company Ltd. In a landmark judgement, the Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person who is self-employed or who is paid fixed wages should be awarded just compensation if he or she becomes a victim of an accident.

summary: The Supreme Court has held that workmen engaged in statutory canteens could be treated as employees of the principal establishment. The appellants are workers who claim to be the deemed employees of the management of Air India on the grounds, inter alia, that they work in a canteen established on the premises of the respondent No. Shri Jayant Bhushan, learned Senior Counsel for the appellants, submits that the appellants-workmen were working in a canteen run by the principal employer.

summary: The Supreme Court has upheld the conviction of a man for setting fire to his wife after she rejected his demand for dowry. The appellant has challenged the conviction and sentence awarded against him by the High Court of Punjab and Haryana on the ground that there was a complete misreading of the oral and documentary evidence and, at every stage, the Courts below adopted its own strange reasoning which was not brought out from the deposition of the witnesses. The evidence of PWs 4 and 5, who deposed as witnesses in the case of murder of Seema Aggarwal, is very compelling.

summary: The Supreme Court of India in a landmark judgement of 2005 held that free and fair elections would alone guarantee the growth of a healthy democracy in the country. summary: Appeal by special leave: Dipak Misra It is the duty of the husband to render the financial support to his wife. summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Union of India and the State of Jammu & Kashmir on a writ petition challenging the constitutional validity of Section 19 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988. Section 19 of the Prevention of Corruption (PC) Act has been challenged in the Supreme Court by Manzoor Ali Khan on the ground that it confers unguided and arbitrary discretion on the Government to grant or not to grant sanction to prosecute corrupt and dishonest politicians, M.Ps, M.L.As and Government officials. Section 19 of the Prevention of Corruption (Amendment) Act, 2014 has been challenged in the Supreme Court by a retired judge of the High Court of India, Manzoor Ali Khan.

summary: The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has published its latest set of judgments in the case of Kala Devi & Ors vs Bhagwan Das Chauhan & Ors. The High Court of Himachal Pradesh held that the appellants were entitled for a compensation of Rs.6,000,000/- for loss of dependency on the deceased's income and on the basis of the gross monthly income of the deceased at the time of his death which was arrived at as Rs.3,000/- p.m. The appellants have been awarded compensation by this Court for injuries sustained by them in an accident which took place on 31 October, 2014.

The High Court has, as noted above, answered that question in the negative; and set aside the award holding that the expression ‘findings’ must include the reasons for the ultimate conclusion arrived at by the Arbitrator. summary: The appellant Raghubir Singh is an employee of the Haryana Roadways. The appellant had raised an industrial dispute against the respondent in the Labour Court of Haryana under Article 311(2)(b) of the Constitution of India and the respondent had terminated the services of the appellant without complying with the principles of natural justice. The Supreme Court of India has held that the reference of an existing industrial dispute between the workman and the employer to either the Labour Court or the Industrial Tribunal for adjudication is an administrative function of the Government as expression is understood in contradistinction judicial or quasi-judicial function.

summary: The Supreme Court has taken up the appeal of a man sentenced to undergo life imprisonment and his father to undergo simple imprisonment for an offence punishable under the Indian Penal Code and the Arms Act. On the night of 6 January, 2014, at Bellur village in the district of Bellur in the state of Karnataka, a group of people, including a woman and two children, were on their way home when they came across a man, Chandrashekar, who had been shot at by a group of armed men. We are of the opinion that the conviction of the appellant under Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code cannot be sustained.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued a series of judgements and orders in the case of Sardar Tajender Singh Gambhir & Anr vs Sardar Gur Singh & Ors. summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) on a petition challenging an order of the High Court of Bombay quashing the criminal proceedings against three accused in the 1993 serial blasts case. summary: The Punjab and Haryana High Court has upheld an eviction order of the Rent Controller, Phagwara, dismissing a petition under Section 13-B of the East Punjab Urban Land Restriction Act, 1949. In a landmark case, the Punjab and Haryana High Court has held that a non-resident Indian who returns to India and is required for his or her use or for the use of any one ordinarily living with and dependent on him or her, may apply to the Controller for immediate possession of buildings, as the case may be, let out by him or her, if the same is required by such non-resident Indian for his or her use or for the use of any one ordinarily living with and dependent on him or her. The appellant has made a specific averment to the effect that the appellant is the owner of the building bearing No.XVI/258/1, situate at Banga Road, Phagwara, comprising 15 shops and open courtyard, as described in the plan attached with the eviction petition.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the State of Tamil Nadu and Respondents to appeals filed by Dr. Subramanian Swamy and T. Sivaraman against the impugned judgment and order passed in Writ Appeal No.181 of 2009 by the High Court of Tamil Nadu rejecting the writ petitioner Podhu Dikshitars to administer the Sabhayanagar Temple. The Dikshitars of Sri Shirur Mutt challenged the orders of the Commissioner of Religious Endowments, Tamil Nadu and the Commissioner of Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras dated 31.7.1987 and 31.8.1951 issued by them defining the duties and powers of the Executive Officer, so appointed for the administration of the Temple. The Podhu Dikshitars of Tirunelveli have challenged the order of the Madras High Court declaring them as a religious denomination’ and divesting them of their right to manage and administer the properties of the Tirunelveli Temple.

summary: The High Court of Judicature at Bombay has set aside a judgment and decree passed by the Additional District Judge in Civil Appeal No.33 of 1987 and restored that passed by the Trial Court dismissing Regular Civil Suit No.87 of 1984. The case dates back to 1987 when Shri Narayan Keshav Ghosalkar and Shri Krishnabai Narayan Ghosalkar were granted a license by the Bombay High Court to occupy the premises of the plaintiff’s law firm. The High Court has held that a suit for possession of premises can be brought only on proof of the primary case and not on proof of the alternative case set up by the plaintiff in the plaint.

summary: The High Court of Assam has granted special leave to the State of Assam and Gauhati Metropolitan Development Authority to appeal against an order passed by a Division Bench of the High Court of Assam at Guahati set aside and the respondents held entitled to restoration of the possession of the land in dispute. The appellant's case is that possession of the allotted land was handed over to GMDA on 25th December, 2003 which action came under challenge at the instance of the respondents in Writ Petition No.2519 of 2004, who stepped into the shoes of Bhabadeb Sarma upon his death on 3rd October, 1997. Section 3 (supra) of the Assam Principal Act, 1935, which deals with vesting of vacant land in the State Government, has been upheld by the Supreme Court in the case of State Of Assam & Ors vs Bhaskar Jyoti Sarma & Ors.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken cognisance of a complaint filed by a woman against a sub-broker of Karvy Stock Broking Limited and other officials of the company for allegedly kidnapping and assaulting her and her husband at Raghunathganj Darbeshpara in Murshidabad district of West Bengal. The appellants have challenged an order of the Chief Judicial Magistrate of the City of Kolkata passing an order cognizance of offences under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) against them. In our series of letters from African journalists, film-maker and columnist Adaobi Tricia Nwaubani looks at the issue of Magistrate examination in criminal cases.

summary: All references are copyrighted. Hindustan Zinc Ltd has challenged the show cause notices issued by the excise department under Rule 57 CC of the Central Excise Tariff Act, 1944 on the ground that the Central Government by subordinate legislation can not fix rates of duties which is the prerogative of the Parliament under Section 3 of the Central Excise Tariff Act, 1975. In the case of Sterlite (supra), the Central Excise Tribunal held that Rule 57 CC will apply only when same inputs are being used in manufacture of two or more final products, one of which is exempt from payment of excise duty and the assessee was not maintaining separate account and separate inventory.

summary: The appellants are Sahara India Real Estate Corporation Limited (SIRE) and Sahara Housing Investment Corporation Limited (SHICL) (referred to as ‘Saharas’ for short) invited and claim to have collected deposits from general public including cobblers, labourers, artisans and peasants in the form of what were described as ‘Optional Fully Convertible Debentures’ (OFCD). The Sahara India Real Estate Corporation (Sahara) appeals against an order of the Sahara Asset Reconstruction Tribunal (SAT) and the High Court of India which had directed them to deposit with the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) a sum of 17,400/- Crores as part of a refund to investors who had subscribed through them. Here is the full text of the order passed by the Delhi High Court on 4 June, 2014 in the case of Sahara India Real Estate Corporation Ltd.

summary: The Supreme Court has held that the Delhi High Court was wrong to order the release on security of a vehicle, which was found to have 47 cartons of Besto Whisky and 27 Cartons of Mashaledar country-made liquor. The appellant has moved the Court of Appeal against the order of the High Court of Delhi, dated 6 January, 2014 which directed the release on security of the vehicle seized under Section 58 of the Delhi Excise Act. The Supreme Court has said that the Delhi High Court has jurisdiction to make any order with regard to the property used in commission of any offence under the Delhi Police Act.

summary: The High Court of Punjab and Haryana has granted special leave to a group of constables to appeal against an order of the Central Administrative Tribunal, Chandigarh, that they should not be promoted to the post of Head Constable on the basis of their revised seniority. The applicants for the post of Head Constables in the Police Training College, Phillaur, Chandigarh, submitted that the selection process for sending them to the Lower School Course at the Police Training College, Phillaur, Chandigarh, should have been carried out in accordance with the pre-amended Rules, i.e. The Punjab and Haryana Police Recruitment Tribunal has held that the process of promotion to the rank of Head Constable started at the time of selection for the Police Training College, Phillaur and that every Constable had the right to be sent for the promotional course at the Police Training College, Phillaur in order of his seniority determined in accordance with that Rule.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that a special leave petition (Crl.) No.8395 of 2012 can be heard by the High Court of Calcutta, which had rejected an application filed by the prosecution under Section 311 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (for short, ‘the code’) to recall the Investigating Officer. The appellants-accused were acquitted by the trial court after the Investigating Officer of the case was re-examined under Section 311 of the Indian Penal Code. Section 311 of the new Code of Criminal Procedure provides that a court may recall a witness or examine any person in attendance at any stage of enquiry, trial or other proceeding.

summary: The appellant, Raman, a four year old boy, was electrocuted on the roof of his house by coming in direct contact with the naked electric wire lying open on the roof of his house. This is an appeal by the State Electricity Board against an order of the High Court of Haryana which had awarded compensation to the victim of electrocution. The court has directed the respondent-Nigam to deposit an amount of Rs.30 Lakhs as compensation to the petitioner in a separate savings bank account in the name of the petitioner's minor Raman in the name of the petitioner and the parents payable to the petitioner on regular monthly basis to be applied for the care of the petitioner on regular monthly basis.

summary: The following is a verbatim transcript of the proceedings of the City Civil Court, Hyderabad, in the case of Union of India & Ors vs Vasavi Co-op. Housing Society Ltd., the first respondent herein instituted a suit No.794 of 1988 before the City Civil Court, Hyderabad, seeking a declaration of title over land comprising 6 acres 30 guntas in Survey No.60/1 and 61 of Kakaguda village and recovery of the vacant possession. The Plaintiffs, as already stated, had entered into various sale deeds with Rama Reddy during the year 1981-82 by which land measuring 13 acres and 08 guntas in Survey No.60, 11 acres and 04 guntas in Survey No.61 and 17 acres and 20 guntas in Survey No.62 were purchased, that is in all 41 acres and 32 guntas. This is a case of dispute over ownership and possession of Cantonment in Kakaguda village of Karimnagar district of Telangana.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the High Court in the state of Uttar Pradesh has the power to issue writs in the nature of Certiorari thereby quashing the impugned impugned. The High Court of Uttar Pradesh has stayed the arrest of Hema Mishra, an assistant teacher in a government school in Barabanki, who is accused of forgery and cheating. Shri Luthra submitted that since the appellant has no legal right to move for anticipatory bail and that practice is not an integral part of Article 226 of the Constitution of India, the contention that the High Court has failed to examine the charges levelled against the appellant, was mala fide or violative of Articles 14 and 21 of the Constitution of India, does not arise.

summary: Appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment and order passed by the High Court of Karnataka Regular First Appeal No.396 of 2007 of the respondent was allowed, reversing the judgment of the trial court and dismissing the suit for specific performance of the agreement filed by the plaintiff-appellant. The appellant-plaintiff entered into an agreement of sale with the defendant-respondent for an out-house in the name of B.R. Sheshadri, brother of the respondent-defendant, for the purpose of securing a loan and the property was mortgaged as a security for the loan. The High Court has held that the conduct of the plaintiff-appellant in executing an agreement of sale in favour of the defendant in favour of the plaintiff-appellant is not legally enforceable and accordingly the appellate court has committed serious illegality in ignoring the material evidence on record with regard to the conduct of the plaintiff-appellant.

summary: The appellant, Vasant Sampat Dupare, was convicted and sentenced to death by the Nagpur bench of the Bombay High Court for raping and murdering a four-year-old girl. On the complaint of the mother of the minor girl, Pinki, PW-1, the Khadgaon police registered a case against the appellant Ashwin Prakash Agrawal under Sections 363 IPC, 367(2)(f) and 201 of the IPC. The learned trial Judge found the appellant guilty of the offences and treated the same as a crime of extreme brutality, for he had committed rape on a minor girl aged about four years without thinking about the effect on the victim.

summary: The Supreme Court of India is hearing seven appeals relating to the issue of payment of salaries to teachers of privately managed primary schools and primary sections of privately managed high schools in Uttar Pradesh. This is an appeal against a decision of the High Court of Uttar Pradesh that teachers of the primary sections of recognised junior basic schools, junior high schools and high schools were not entitled to payment of their salaries under the Payment of Salary Act, 1978. The Supreme Court has ruled that Assistant Teachers of a recognised school in Uttar Pradesh should be paid salary under the 1978 Education (Basic) Act.

summary: The Supreme Court of India is hearing a petition challenging the validity of Article 15 of the Indian Constitution, which gives special status to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. A Bench of the Supreme Court of India, headed by Justice Dipak Misra, is hearing a batch of writ petitions challenging the validity of clause (5) of Article 15 of the Constitution relating to private unaided educational institutions. The Attorney General of India, Mukul Rohatgi, has submitted that the Supreme Court in Minerva Mills case (supra) has held that Parliament has no power to amend the Constitution on the ground that it damages the basic structure of the Constitution and destroys its basic structure by a total exclusion of challenge to any law on the ground that it is inconsistent with, or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by Article 14 or Article 19 of the Constitution.

summary: The appellants as well as the private respondents are aspirants for the single post of Chief Engineer in the Parishad which fell vacant in January 2011. On 27.3.2012, the High Court of Madhya Pradesh in its order dated 27.3.2012 directed the State Government to fill up the post of Chief Engineer by regular promotion in accordance with the provisions of Regulation 20 of the U.P. Avas Evam Vikas Parishad (Appointment and Conditions of Service of Chief Engineer) Regulations, 1990 which had been declared ultra vires. On 23.8.2012, a Parishad of the Madhya Pradesh Government, under the chairmanship of Rajendra Kumar Agrawal, approved a decision of relaxation in the eligibility criteria for promotion to the post of Chief Engineer.

summary: The Karnataka High Court has set aside the Judgment and Order of the J.M.F.C. The appellant-accused was found guilty under Section 138 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) for cheating, cheating by false pretences and criminal conspiracy after he was found guilty of accepting a Cheque of Rs.5,00, issued by Akshya Bank in the name of the Page 5 appellant, which was meant for the repayment of advanced amount of Rs.1,75,000/-. In the absence of any material evidence in support of the claim of the respondent-complainant, we cannot uphold the impugned judgment.

summary: The Supreme Court has upheld the conviction and seven-year jail term of Naresh Kumar for murdering his wife Rekha Rani for demanding dowry. The appellant has been convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment by the trial Court for the offence of dowry harassment under Section 304 B, IPC. The High Court of Delhi has upheld the conviction of a man for dowry-related murder of his wife who took her own life by setting herself on fire.
